abstracts.cdata!:
This project was designed to support the
            first phase of a two-phased Energy Efficiency Program in
            Brazil. Since project approval in October 1999,
            implementation was hampered by two main events. First, there
            was delay in project effectiveness. The project was
            originally scheduled to become effective in January 2000 but
            did not become effective until February 2001. Second, not
            long after project effectiveness, in May 2001 the Government
            declared a major energy supply crisis which significantly
            dampened the incentives for distribution companies to
            execute the proposed project activities. There are two main
            lessons from the project that should be used in subsequent
            World Bank energy efficiency projects. (1) Demand-side
            management (DSM) programs can be successful only if the
            underlying incentives of the regulatory framework are in
            place and correct. (2) The rationing program that was put in
            place in 2002 to deal with severe cuts in electricity supply
            was effective in reducing consumption, but also resulted in
            large financial losses to the distribution utilities that
            have been being made up through utility bills since the crisis.
